ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My critical thinking and writing skills improved immensely throughout this course; not only did I learn a lot about the topics of democracy, truth, and misinformation, but I became more effective in thinking philosophically and crafting arguments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The in-class discussions of the reading were very strong and engaging, and the individual attention given to our writing by Professor Riley was very helpful. The only change that might benefit the course would be more workshop-style lessons to directly improve our analytical writing.

Strengths: The in-class discussions were interesting. Professor Riley gave very helpful feedback on my writing and I think the quality of my arguments and writing style improved a lot over the semester. 

Weaknesses: I felt like the discussions were on topics unrelated to the papers we were writing at times. Honestly I was a little bored of the topic by the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to any student interested in politics and society, especially someone who wants to engage in their own thinking and discussing rather than being buried in loads of reading.
Yes, but expect to spend a lot of time writing.
